H0.text: Fungi were long considered part of the plant kingdom because of obvious similarities; both are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

H1.text: Mosses were long considered part of the plant kingdom because of obvious similarities; both are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

H2.text: Coral was long considered part of the plant kingdom because both coral and plants are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

H3.text: Bacteria were long considered part of the plant kingdom because of obvious similarities; both are immobile, have cell walls, and grow in soil.

A4.text: Taxonomists considered fungi to be members of the plant kingdom because of similarities in lifestyle: both fungi and plants are mainly immobile, and have similarities in general morphology and growth habit.

A5.text: Although commonly included in botany curricula and textbooks, fungi are more closely related to animals than to plants, and are placed with the animals in the monophyletic group of opisthokonts.

A6.text: current definitions exclude fungi and some of the algae.

A7.text: the embryophytes or land plants (hornworts, liverworts, mosses, lycophytes, ferns, conifers and other gymnosperms, and flowering plants).
